APPROPRIATION BILL


    Order for Second and Third Readings read.

2.33 p.m.

    The Minister of Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's recommendation that this Bill be proceeded with.

    Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Main Estimates of Revenue and Expenditure for the year 1962 have been considered and approved by the Assembly as Paper Cmd. No. 35 of 1961.

    It is now necessary to give legislative approval to the expenditure of the sums shown in these Estimates, and the annual Appropriation Bill now before Members is intended to so provide.

    Under section 97(1) of the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council, 1958, an Appropriation Bill containing, under

Column: 2336

appropriate heads of expenditure, the sums of money which are required for the several services of government shall be introduced into the Assembly. The Appropriation Bill lays out all the amounts approved by the Assembly in the Estimates of Expenditure and arranged under the Heads of Expenditure shown on pages 41 and 42 of Cmd. No. 35 of 1961. Once the Appropriation Bill has been approved, the Minister for Finance will be empowered to issue warrants authorising expenditure up to the amount under each Head in the Appropriation Bill to be paid out of the Consolidated Fund.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, there is one point on which I wish to touch, and that is Head 33 in the Schedule - Charge on Account of the Public Debt.

    On the first occasion when the Budget was presented to the Assembly by the present Government, I raised one or two queries on the items set out under Head 33- Charge on Account of the Public Debt - and you, Mr Speaker, ruled me out of order because they were statutory debts.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, under Head 33, the total figure to be allocated is set out on page 350 of the Estimates, and on pages 41 and 42 is an abstract of estimated expenditure for the year 1962, showing statutory expenditure and the amounts to be voted. Now under Head 33, the statutory expenditure is $20,549,310 and the amount to be voted by the Legislative Assembly is $1,500,710. When one examines these items, one notices two points. The first point I wish to bring to the attention of the House is subheads 4 and 5. Subhead 4 is Discount on Treasury Bills . . . . $1,500,000, and subhead 5 is Interest on Treasury Deposits .... $1,600,000. The point I wish to make is that these two subheads appear as statutory expenditure and, therefore, the Assembly has no control over its expenditure. But the difficulty here is that these are interest payments on debts

Column: 2337

which are not yet incurred and, therefore, my contention is that any interest payment on debt not yet incurred is not a public debt.

    Section 97(4) of the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council, 1958, sets out the heads of statutory expenditure and one of such heads is section 100 which reads:

    'The public debt of Singapore is hereby charged on the Consolidated Fund.'

What I would like to ask the Minister for Finance is this. If he does not raise money by way of Treasury bills or does not take in Treasury deposits, then these two sums do not become payable by way of interest. That being so, how can he then come to the Assembly and say that this is statutory expenditure and that the Assembly has no control over it? This seems to be a left-handed way by means of which Government can raise money without the consent and, if I may say, Sir, without the knowledge of the Assembly regarding the purpose of expenditure. Assuming that a discount on Treasury bills is obtained at an average rate of five per cent interest, then under subhead 4, Govermnent can borrow about $30 million for 1962. Similarly, they can borrow another $30 million by way of Treasury deposits under subhead 5. So that the Government is then enabled, by the use of subheads 4 and 5, to borrow up to $60 million without the consent of the House. That is the first point, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    The second point to which I wish to draw the attention of the Minister for Finance is this. Under subhead 10 on page 350 of the Estimates, there is a sum of $1,500,000 which appears as Repay ment of War Damage Interest-Free Loan, but that apparently is not a public debt. Although it seems to be a debt which is being paid out of the Consolidated Fund, yet it does not appear under Head 33 as a Charge on Account of the Public Debt, because the Minister is, in fact, asking the Assembly to vote $1.5 million for the repayment of war damage interest-free loan. Perhaps the Minister might care to explain to the

Column: 2338

House why it is that this particular debt is treated as if it were not a public debt.

    Mr Speaker: Dr Goh, in reply.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: I have been assured of the correctness of regarding interest paid on Treasury bills and Treasury deposits as coming within the terms of Charge on Account of the Public Debt. Therefore, it is statutory expenditure which need not require the assent of this House before it is paid. However, I think the Member for Farrer Park has a point, that in respect of long-term le2ns, it is necessary for the Government to seek the approval of the House - at any rate as regards the maximum limit to which we can borrow by way of loans from the public. But as regards the Treasury bills and Treasury deposits, reference to this House is not necessary. I am not quite sure what the legal position is in this respect, because Treasury bills have the authority of an Ordinance which was passed by the former Legislature, and I am not certain whether or not any ceiling has been imposed on the amount that Government can so borrow. It could well be that a ceiling has been imposed under that Ordinance on the amount that could be borrowed by the Government through Treasury bills.

    As regards the second point, that is the repayment of war damage interest-free loan, the position is this. Before World War II, there was a compulsory war damage insurance scheme to which various categories of business were required to contribute. After the war, the damage was assessed and large amounts were paid out by way of war damage compensation. The funds available under the war damage insurance scheme were not adequate to meet all the claims for war damage, and the U.K. Government had to come to the assistance of both the Singapore Government and the Federation Government. I think this was in 1948 or thereabouts - just a few years after the end of the Second World War. Part of the financial assistance was made by way of grants and part was made by way of interest-free loans. Although the loan carried no interest, it is necessary,

Column: 2339

of course, to make annual repayments of principal, and this is the contribution which the Singapore Government has to make to the U.K. Government in repayment of this loan. There is still another 15 years to go. I think it is for this reason that the repayment of this loan has not been regarded legally to fall within the terms of Charge on Account of the Public Debt as defined in the Constitution.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time.
Third Reading

UNIVERSITY OF SINGAPORE BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.46 p.m.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The University of Malaya was established on 8th October, 1949, as a national institution to serve the higher educational needs of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya. The origins of the University could be traced back to the founding in Singapore of the King Edward VII College of Medicine in 1905 and Raffles College in 1929. Both these Colleges gradually expanded to serve the educational needs of the increasing population of Malaya until World War II intervened in 1942.

    In 1947 a Commission was appointed under the chairmanship of Sir Alexander Carr-Saunders to inquire into and make recommendations concerning university education in Malaya. As a result of the

Column: 2340

recommendations of this Commission, the University of Malaya was founded in 1949. Although the Commission recommended that the two Colleges should form the nucleus of the new University, it also anticipated the rapid demand for higher education in a swiftly expanding population of the two territories, and so it recommended that the new University should consider moving into South Johore in order that future expansion would not be hindered for lack of space. However, this did not materialise because of the enormous cost involved, and the scheme had to be abandoned in 1954.

    In 1957 a Commission of Inquiry headed by Dr R. S. Aitken was set up by the Governments of Singapore and the Federation, this time at the request of the University, in order to review the constitution, working, and finances of the University in the light of experience and rapid expansion of the last seven years, and of the prospective expansion in the near future, including the plan for developing the University in Kuala Lumpur, and to make recommendations. Arising from the Commission's Report and resulting from the recommendations of the two joint Committees on Constitution and Finance appointed by the two Governments, legislation was passed in November 1958 providing for the continuance of the University of Malaya as a single university but with the establishment of two largely autonomous Divisions of equal status, one in Singapore and the other at Kuala Lumpur. This legislation came into effect on 15th January, 1959.

    The University's running expenses continued to be met from grants from the Governments of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya, hitherto made on a quinquennial basis in the ratio 40 : 60, on the basis of student numbers from the two territories. But in 1959 they were amended to a triennial basis for the period 1959-61 and the ratio changed to a basis of 1: 2. It was also expected that by 1962 each Government would be responsible for looking after its own Division and at the same time contributing towards the annual recurrent cost of

Column: 2341

the other Division in respect of its students attending courses not available in its own Division. Capital grants, however, would continue to be made on an equal basis during the triennium.

    In May 1960 the Governments of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya indicated their intention to establish autonomous separate national universities in Singapore and the Federation by 1962. Steps were accordingly taken in both territories to redraft new constitutions for each Division to found two separate national universities. At the request of the Divisional Council of the University of Malaya (Singapore Division), a joint Government/University committee of seven were appointed in June this year for this purpose. And the present draft Bill was submitted to both the Divisional Senate and Divisional Council for their views. I might add that the Singapore Joint Government/University Committee were in the happy position of being able to use the draft Bill of the Federation's Joint Government/University Committee in its deliberations. On the whole, our Bill closely follows the present pattern of the Constitution of the University of Malaya so that a feeling of continuity with the old is being maintained. The present Bill has also incorporated all material points suggested by both the Divisional Senates and Council of the University of Malaya (Singapore Division). Our Bill is also closely in line with the main provision of the University of Malaya Act which was passed in the Federation Parliament this year.

    I should now like to enumerate the important differences between the provisions of the present Bill with those of the present Constitution of the University of Malaya Ordinance, No. 12 of 1949, and as further amended by Ordinance No. 7 of 1954 and Ordinance No. 44 of 1958. Firstly, there was no provision in the past for the University to grant external degrees. Our draft Bill permits this under clause 4 (b) (ii) at page 9, Part II of the Constitution. The

Column: 2342

marginal note reads, "Powers of the University":-

    'The University shall, subject to the proviions of this Constitution, have power -

    (b) to confer degrees upon persons who have -
* * *


    (ii) satisfied such requirements as may be prescribed by Act;'.

I am sure Members of this House will welcome this provision.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): Hear, hear!

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Singapore being a City State and highly urbanised, it is but fit and proper that adults who of some reason or other could not join the University after a brilliant academic record in school, and for some reason or other, perhaps on economic grounds, are unable to pursue higher education and have to get down to the business of employment, should be given the opportunity to catch up if they wish to burn the midnight oil and pursue their intellectual pursuits.

    Secondly, membership of the Court. I am referring to page 25 of the University of Malaya calendar year 1960-61. Although under clause 15 (g) of the present Constitution four persons are appointed by the Yang di-Pertuan Agong to the Court, under clause 13 (g) of the draft Bill at page 13:-

    'The Court shall consist of -
* * *


    (g) two persons appointed by the Yang di-Pertuan Agong;'.

So although our draft Bill has reduced this number from four to two, provision has been made for the appointment of three additional members, namely, one person appointed by the Sultan of Brunei, one person appointed by the Governor of North Borneo, and one person appointed by the Governor of Sarawak. There are similar reciprocal provisions in the Federation of Malaya Act, 1961, for the Court of the new University of Malaya. In view of the current merger talks and the proposed new Federation of Malaysia, I am sure Members of this House will welcome the provisions of membership of the Court

Column: 2343

whereby the close association with our brothers in the Borneo territories are being embodied in the Constitution of our University. Provision has also been made for the following additional members to he admitted to the Court of our future University of Singapore. If we turn to page 14, clause 13, paragraph (n):

    'the head or director or such other representative as may from time to time he appointed by the governing body of each of the following:-

    (i) the Lembaga Gerakan Pelajaran Dewasa;
* * *


    (iii) the University of Malaya established by the University of Malaya Act, 1961;
* * *


    (v) the Dewan Bahasa dan Kebudayaan Kebangsaan;

    (vi) the Dewan Bahasa dan Pustaka, Federation of Malaya;'.

    Thirdly, membership of the Council. Although the representation of the Council has not been altered, remaining at 20, with the Government having three representatives being officials holding the posts of Permanent Secretary in the Ministries of Treasury, Education and Health, our draft Bill has amended this clause to read as follows - if we refer to page 15, clause 16:

    'The Council shall consist of -
* * *


    (f) three persons to be appointed by the Government of Singapore;'.

Such a provision will allow for more flexibility in the appointment of officials and also for continuity.

    I come now to the transitional provisions of the Bill. It will be noted that under clause 49, at page 23, the first Chancellor of the proposed University of Singapore will be an appointment by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara on the advice of the present Divisional Council of the University of Malaya in Singapore.

    Clause 50 provides for the present holder of the principalship of the University of Malaya in Singapore to become the first Vice-Chancellor of the new University.

    Mr David Marshall: How long?

Column: 2344



    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Clause 54, if you turn to page 24 of the Bill, provides for the continuation of the present Divisional Council of the University of Malaya in Singapore to be the first Council of the University for a period of one year or such shorter period as may in the opinion of the Vice-Chancellor be deemed necessary.

    Clause 55 provides for the present Guild of Graduates of the University of Malaya to be divided into two Guilds; that is, the Guild of Graduates of the University of Singapore and the Guild of Graduates of the new University of Malaya, at the option of the graduates. Such option could be exercised within a period of twelve months, and if such option is not exercised during the period mentioned, then the last known address of the graduate will .be taken as a basis for going on to the register. I may add that there is a similar clause in the not disposed of of the present University of Malay.

    Lastly, clause 62, at page 25, provides for the setting up of a Joint Winding-up Committee of eight persons to take over the powers now vested in the Central Council and any other central authority of the University of Malaya. It will have up to two years to wind up affairs still not disposed of of the present University of Malaya.

    The Bill will not involve the expenditure of additional money. Annual estimates for recurrent annual expenditure and for special expenditure will be submitted by the University in the usual manner annually.

    The Government is confident that with the establishment of the University of Singapore, more facilities will be provided both in the field of expansion of courses of studies and the number in the intake of students annually.

    Singapore is a growing State both in status and in its population. With the rapid expansion in secondary education in all the four language streams, it is to he expected that yet greater demands will he made for the provision of higher studies, With the provision thus made,

Column: 2345

it is hoped that less and less of our students need go overseas to pursue their higher studies for a first degree. Perhaps I should conclude by adding that it is the intention of my opposite number in the Government of the Federation of Malaya and myself to see that both national universities, the University of Singapore and the new University of Malaya at Kuala Lumpur, will come into being on the same day, that is, the 1st of January, 1962, if the Bill meets with the approval of this House.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

    Dr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sure we all welcome this Bill. Although for sentimental reasons we may regret that there cannot be one national university to serve the whole of Malaya, yet we know that for practical purposes, this means that instead of one university, we shall have two, and altogether three Universities in Malaya, including Nanyang University.

    Sir, 15 years ago, when the Carr-Saunders Commission was here, there were still doubts whether there should be a university. They were thinking even in terms of a university college. Yet within 15 years, we have three universities. I am sure that within one more decade people in northern Malaya may be thinking of another university to be sited in Penang or in Ipoh. Then with this idea of a united Malaysia coming to fruition, we can expect Singapore will continue to be very important as an educational centre for South-East Asia. I hope that we shall be drawing students not only from Singapore but also from the neighbouring regions. Sir, I notice that in page 2, paragraph 2 of the Bill, there is a statement to assure that each university will be autonomous. Sir, I am sorry that the Deputy Prime Minister is not present in the House today. I have asked a few members of the staff of the University to take part in politics, and they have expressed the view that they were not very sure whether the present Government would show the same

Column: 2346

degree of tolerance as the previous Government did. I hope that the present Government will be able to give us the assurance that there will be the same degree of courtesy given, and that the Barisan Sosialis will also give the same assurance in case they ever come to power: that is, if any member of the University staff should want to take part in politics in an opposition group, then they would have the same courtesy as they had before. I am sure that in the case of the Member for Anson, he would give that assurance.

    An hon. Member: For expulsion!

    Hon. Members: Hear, hear!

    Dr Thio Chan Bee: Sir, I am not ashamed to say that I was one of those poor fellows who were unable to go to a university and had to study as a external student. We had to do it the hard way. I believe the Member for Anson also did it the hard way. I am glad the chance is now being given to those in Singapore to continue their studies after passing their Cambridge School Certificate or Senior Middle III, so that in spite of adverse circumstances they will still be able to attain the object of their ambition and serve their country in a better way.

    I am sure that we all wish success and still greater success to the University of Singapore in spite of its new name. We believe that the standard will be maintained and that our products will be as good as those that graduated previously. We extend our good wishes, Sir, to the University.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not regret to see the establishment of an autonomous University in Singapore. It is true that the Division of the University of Malaya has been spurred by political motivations. But I do say, Sir, that the requirements of the two territories, and certainly, the requirements of this territory, can only be fulfilled by a university here in Singapore. We have room aplenty for two universities, one in the English language stream and one in the Chinese language stream. I do not view the establishment

Column: 2347

of an autonomous university as being in any way derogatory to the unity of this area. Mr Speaker, there are political divisions which separate us. The University of Malaya, which was a single unit, did assist, I believe, very considerably in bringing about a common approach anti understanding between students from Singapore and the Federation. I believe this will continue despite the division of the University, by the need of each territory to send students to the other territory to study in those faculties which are absent in the local University.

    There is another aspect, Sir, which engages me and compels me to rise to sneak this afternoon. The Minister for Education has told us, and told us correctly, that a university is a national institution. Sir, it is a national institution not merely for the dissemination of knowledge but also for the advancement of knowledge, as I think you will see stated in clause 4 (a) of the Schedule. That is the distinction between a university and a technical college. In a technical college, you acquire knowledge. In a university you do not merely acquire knowledge, but you also expand the frontiers of knowledge. That is by far the more important function of a university, that it should keep alive the human spirit of inquiry, research and independent thinking. Before our youth can be trained in independent thinking, there must be academic freedom for those in whose care they are - the academic staff. My complaint about this Bill is that it does not provide for the protection of academic freedom. Mr Speaker, the leader of the S.P.A., with considerable courtesy, soft-pedaled what is a legitimate fear, and that is the fear of political intimidation whereby academic freedom can be arid is inhibited.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Is the hon. Member for Anson referring to the Member for Tanglin?

    Mr David Marshall: Yes.

Column: 2348



    Mr Speaker: If he is, I do not think the Member for Tanglin claims to be the leader of the S.P.A.

    Mr David Marshall: Sorry, Sir, surely he is the leader of the S.P.A.

    An hon. Member: He is the leader only in this House.

    Mr David Marshall: My apologies. Thank you for the correction. Of course, it is the Member for Cairnhill. Sir, I was saying that this fear is a very real fear. It is a fear which has arisen from certain incidents which have occurred during the short lifetime - not too short; the shorter the better - of this Government. I would like to draw your attention, Sir, to this matter of principle, of the urgent need for the protection of academic freedom and the insertion in this Bill of such protection. I would like to draw the attention of this House to certain correspondence which took place between me and the Principal of the University, who will, under the provisions of this Bill, he the Vice-Chancellor on the 1st of January.

    Sir, on the 14th of October, 1961. I wrote to the Principal, University of Malaya in Singapore:

    'The discussions between the Singapore and the Federation Governments on the issue of Merger have raised, in so far as information is available and will no doubt in future raise matters of constitutional law -'

    Mr Speaker: Order. I do not suppose the Member for Anson is going to read the whole letter, because he is not permitted to do that. All he need do is to read extracts and paraphrase the correspondence.

    Mr David Marshall: If it please you, Mr Speaker, Sir, I thought in fairness to the officer concerned and the principle of academic freedom that is involved. There are four letters. They are all fairly short, Sir,In that case, I shall try to paraphrase and, in fairness then, may I ask that the entire correspondence be tabled, so that it may be available to be checked?

    Mr Speaker: Certainly, that is the correct course. In his speech, the Member for Anson could paraphrase what

Column: 2349

is contained in that correspondence and then later on table it for the information of any Member who wishes to see it.

    Mr David Marshall: I am much obliged, Mr Speaker. I drew the attention of the Principal of the University of Malaya in Singapore to the need for clarification of the public in respect of certain matters which arose on these constitutional issues. I pointed out that, in my view, there was a responsibility on the part of the academic staff of the University to assist the people of Singapore and their elected representatives, and asked whether he would have any objection to my approaching a certain professor of international law with a view of obtaining his views on constitutional issues raised by the joint statements issued by the Prime Ministers. I said "I...write to you to ask whether you agree a member of the academic staff of the University can properly advise political parties...".

    Sir, I did not ask for permission to do so, because, to my mind, a member of the academic staff requires no permission to indulge in such extra curricula activities as he thinks proper so long as they do not encroach upon the time required for the discharge of his responsibilities to the University.

    Sir, I received a reply which slated, in effect, that the University is prepared to permit individual full-time staff of the Law Faculty to give the advice requested if the request is made by the Speaker and is addressed to the Principal. Sir, I thought, in fairness, I should have read the lot, but I now will table it. I can only say this. I take a very grave view of what I consider to be the lack of understanding displayed in that letter of basic, academic traditions. And there are two traditions affected. One is the freedom of the individual academician in his unfettered discretion to advise or not to advise such person or organisation as he thinks fit on such matters as are within his special competence, without any interference of any character whatsoever, on the part of his colleagues or the Vice-Chancellor. The other tradition is the responsibility of the University and its teaching staff to recognise that we do not subsidise

Column: 2350

Tomtits in ivory towers. That is not what we pay millions of dollars for. It is an organisation for the advancement of learning to assist the nation and if and when matters vital to the nation arise and there is an honest request for information within their specific field of competence, then they have a responsibility to advise - a responsibility which, again in their discretion, they may refuse, for good reasons, to comply with.

    Sir, I wrote to the Principal seeking to avoid the possibility of a misunderstanding. At length, I finally received a reply on the 22nd of this month to say that while a member of the University may, subject to limitations imposed by his contract and the ethical code of his profession, freely give advice to anyone, the danger lies in the use to which such advice is put to. He would, of course, he giving advice in his individual capacity, but the quotation of his opinion by a political Party is bound to give rise to the impression that the University is involved in or sympathetic to any particular stand.

    Again, Sir, though much more courteous in tone and to some extent recognising basic academic rights, this letter does substantially say that they are afraid of being involved in political controversies. Therefore, it would he his view (the Vice-Chancellor, the present Principal) that members of the academic stall should not give advice and that they would be discouraged from doing so. It is indeed a pathetic commentary that the University of Singapore, on the eve of its birth, should fail so signally to recognise its responsibility to the people of Singapore, and display a lack of moral courage as indicated in the correspondence to which I have referred and which I would be happy not only to table here but to have it quoted widely.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the fear of the University as displayed by its Principal's letters arises from the conduct of this Government with reference to two persons. But the Government will continue to pursue this matter and hope that the three-man committee who has been agreed between both farmers and sand operators will be able to come to some satisfactory finding. Mr Speaker, Sir, we are doing this for the helpless farmers and fishermen who had for years suffered at the hands of sand operators, landowners and vested interests. For those who think that they can get away with their mischief, the Government will use whatever there is in its power as provided in this Bill to prevent them from causing further damage and nuisance. To those who abide by the law and ensure that, in seeking after profit they will not in any way adversely affect their neighbours' property, the Bill provides a fair and just way for them to continue their occupation.
